identified-content.classifier: Health Maintenance Organizations and Managed Care

abstract.p: Letter from Kenneth E Raske (Greater New York Hospital Association) says departure of health maintenance organizations from Medicare market (June 3 article) can be traced to the excessive Medicare premium cuts enacted in Balanced Budget Act of 1997; cartoon

block.p: Investor-owned health maintenance organizations were financially damaged by Medicare premium cuts enacted in the Balanced Budget Act of 1997; therefore, they are leaving key markets to seek more profitable lines of business (front page, June 3). Because the Medicare premium is based on its component parts, the largest of which is hospital care, an inadequate premium reflects inadequate payments to hospitals.

Investor-owned health maintenance organizations were financially damaged by Medicare premium cuts enacted in the Balanced Budget Act of 1997; therefore, they are leaving key markets to seek more profitable lines of business (front page, June 3). Because the Medicare premium is based on its component parts, the largest of which is hospital care, an inadequate premium reflects inadequate payments to hospitals.

The difference is that hospitals will not abandon their missions like the investor-owned H.M.O.'s. Rather, they are being forced to transfer their losses directly to Medicare patients and all other patients through a decline in the level and array of services provided. Through the action of the H.M.O.'s, the market is telling the government that the budget law cuts went too far, a point that health care providers having been making for two years.
KENNETH E. RASKE President, Greater New York Hospital Association New York, June 5, 2000
